natural problem: How many ways are there to arrange $6$ beads of distinct colors in a $2 \times 3$ grid if reflections and rotations are considered the same? (In other words, two arrangements are considered the same if I can rotate and/or reflect one arrangement to get the other.)
natural solution: There are $6! = 720$ ways to put the beads on the grid ignoring distinguishability. On the other hand, there are $4$ possible transformations of the board using rotations and reflections (including the identity): \begin{tabular}{ccccccc}

A & B & C & & C & B & A\\ D & E & F & & F & E & D \end{tabular}\begin{tabular}{ccccccc} F & E & D & & D & E & F\\ C & B & A & & A & B & C \end{tabular}None of these transformations besides the identity fixes an arrangement, so each arrangement is equivalent to three others.
As a result, there are $\tfrac{720}{4} = \boxed{180}$ different arrangements.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes beads :: nat and grid :: "nat \<times> nat" and arrangements :: nat
assumes h0 : "beads = 6"
and h1 : "grid = (2, 3)"
and h2 : "arrangements = count_distinct_rotations_reflections beads grid"
shows  "arrangements = 180"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many ways are there to arrange $6$ beads of distinct colors in a $2 \times 3$ grid if reflections and rotations are considered the same? (In other words, two arrangements are considered the same if I can rotate and/or reflect one arrangement to get the other.) The final Answer is 180
 ### Proof
 There are $6! = 720$ ways to put the beads on the grid ignoring distinguishability. On the other hand, there are $4$ possible transformations of the board using rotations and reflections (including the identity): \begin{tabular}{ccccccc}
 A & B & C & & C & B & A\\ D & E & F & & F & E & D \end{tabular}\begin{tabular}{ccccccc} F & E & D & & D & E & F\\ C & B & A & & A & B & C \end{tabular}None of these transformations besides the identity fixes an arrangement, so each arrangement is equivalent to three others.
 As a result, there are $\tfrac{720}{4} = \boxed{180}$ different arrangements.
 *)

theorem
fixes beads :: nat and grid :: "nat \<times> nat" and arrangements :: nat
assumes h0 : "beads = 6"
and h1 : "grid = (2, 3)"
and h2 : "arrangements = count_distinct_rotations_reflections beads grid"
shows  "arrangements = 180"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: You have 6 beads and a 2x3 grid. Find the number of distinct arrangements of the beads on the grid, taking into account rotations and reflections. The final answer is 180.

 How many ways are there to arrange $6$ beads of distinct colors in a $2 \times 3$ grid if reflections and rotations are considered the same? (In other words, two arrangements are considered the same if I can rotate and/or reflect one arrangement to get the other.) The final Answer is 180

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes arrangements :: nat
assumes h0 : "arrangements = card {p :: (nat, nat) \<Rightarrow> nat. bijective p \<and> (\<forall> x y. p (x, y) \<le> 6)}"
and h1 : "equiv {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6} {p :: (nat, nat) \<Rightarrow> nat. bijective p \<and> (\<forall> x y. p (x, y) \<le> 6)} (symmetric rotations and reflections)"
shows  "arrangements = 180"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many ways are there to arrange $6$ beads of distinct colors in a $2 \times 3$ grid if reflections and rotations are considered the same? (In other words, two arrangements are considered the same if I can rotate and/or reflect one arrangement to get the other.) The final Answer is 180
 ### Proof
 There are $6! = 720$ ways to put the beads on the grid ignoring distinguishability. On the other hand, there are $4$ possible transformations of the board using rotations and reflections (including the identity): \begin{tabular}{ccccccc}
 A & B & C & & C & B & A\\ D & E & F & & F & E & D \end{tabular}\begin{tabular}{ccccccc} F & E & D & & D & E & F\\ C & B & A & & A & B & C \end{tabular}None of these transformations besides the identity fixes an arrangement, so each arrangement is equivalent to three others.
 As a result, there are $\tfrac{720}{4} = \boxed{180}$ different arrangements.
 *)

theorem
fixes arrangements :: nat
assumes h0 : "arrangements = card {p :: (nat, nat) \<Rightarrow> nat. bijective p \<and> (\<forall> x y. p (x, y) \<le> 6)}"
and h1 : "equiv {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6} {p :: (nat, nat) \<Rightarrow> nat. bijective p \<and> (\<forall> x y. p (x, y) \<le> 6)} (symmetric rotations and reflections)"
shows  "arrangements = 180"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: How many distinct arrangements can be created with the numbers 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6, where each arrangement is a bijective function from a pair of natural numbers (x, y) to a natural number less than or equal to 6, considering symmetric rotations and reflections as equivalent? The final answer is 180 arrangements.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 6"
and h1 : "distinct_colors n"
and h2 : "grid_size = (2, 3)"
and h3 : "reflections_and_rotations_are_same"
shows  "arrangement_ways = 180"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many ways are there to arrange $6$ beads of distinct colors in a $2 \times 3$ grid if reflections and rotations are considered the same? (In other words, two arrangements are considered the same if I can rotate and/or reflect one arrangement to get the other.) The final Answer is 180

 A & B & C & & C & B & A\\ D & E & F & & F & E & D \end{tabular}\begin{tabular}{ccccccc} F & E & D & & D & E & F\\ C & B & A & & A & B & C \end{tabular}None of these transformations besides the identity fixes an arrangement, so each arrangement is equivalent to three others.
 As a result, there are $\tfrac{720}{4} = \boxed{180}$ different arrangements.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 6"
and h1 : "distinct_colors n"
and h2 : "grid_size = (2, 3)"
and h3 : "reflections_and_rotations_are_same"
shows  "arrangement_ways = 180"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: In a 2x3 grid, you have 6 distinct colors to fill the cells. If reflections and rotations of the grid are considered the same arrangement, find the number of different ways to arrange the colors. The final answer is 180.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes beads grid :: nat
assumes h0 : "beads = 6"
and h1 : "grid = 2 * 3"
and h2 : "distinct_colors beads"
shows  "count_arrangements beads grid reflections rotations = 180"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many ways are there to arrange $6$ beads of distinct colors in a $2 \times 3$ grid if reflections and rotations are considered the same? (In other words, two arrangements are considered the same if I can rotate and/or reflect one arrangement to get the other.) The final Answer is 180
 ### Proof

 A & B & C & & C & B & A\\ D & E & F & & F & E & D \end{tabular}\begin{tabular}{ccccccc} F & E & D & & D & E & F\\ C & B & A & & A & B & C \end{tabular}None of these transformations besides the identity fixes an arrangement, so each arrangement is equivalent to three others.
 As a result, there are $\tfrac{720}{4} = \boxed{180}$ different arrangements.
 *)

theorem
fixes beads grid :: nat
assumes h0 : "beads = 6"
and h1 : "grid = 2 * 3"
and h2 : "distinct_colors beads"
shows  "count_arrangements beads grid reflections rotations = 180"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes num_beads :: nat and grid_size :: "nat \<times> nat" and arrangements :: nat
assumes h0 : "num_beads = 6"
and h1 : "grid_size = (2, 3)"
and h2 : "arrangements = 180"
shows  "arrangements = (GREATEST a. \<exists> f. f num_beads grid_size = a)"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many ways are there to arrange $6$ beads of distinct colors in a $2 \times 3$ grid if reflections and rotations are considered the same? (In other words, two arrangements are considered the same if I can rotate and/or reflect one arrangement to get the other.) The final Answer is 180
 ### Proof
 There are $6! = 720$ ways to put the beads on the grid ignoring distinguishability. On the other hand, there are $4$ possible transformations of the board using rotations and reflections (including the identity): \begin{tabular}{ccccccc}
 A & B & C & & C & B & A\\ D & E & F & & F & E & D \end{tabular}\begin{tabular}{ccccccc} F & E & D & & D & E & F\\ C & B & A & & A & B & C \end{tabular}None of these transformations besides the identity fixes an arrangement, so each arrangement is equivalent to three others.
 As a result, there are $\tfrac{720}{4} = \boxed{180}$ different arrangements.
 *)

theorem
fixes num_beads :: nat and grid_size :: "nat \<times> nat" and arrangements :: nat
assumes h0 : "num_beads = 6"
and h1 : "grid_size = (2, 3)"
and h2 : "arrangements = 180"
shows  "arrangements = (GREATEST a. \<exists> f. f num_beads grid_size = a)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Given a grid of size 2 by 3 and 6 beads, find the greatest possible number of arrangements for the beads. The final answer is 180.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes arrangements :: nat
assumes h0 : "arrangements = card {P :: (nat \<times> nat) \<Rightarrow> nat. bij P \<and> (\<forall>i j. P (i, j) \<noteq> P (j, i)) \<and> (\<forall>i j. P (i, j) \<noteq> P (2 - i, j)) \<and> (\<forall>i j. P (i, j) \<noteq> P (i, 3 - j))}"
shows  "arrangements = 180"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many ways are there to arrange $6$ beads of distinct colors in a $2 \times 3$ grid if reflections and rotations are considered the same? (In other words, two arrangements are considered the same if I can rotate and/or reflect one arrangement to get the other.) The final Answer is 180
 ### Proof
 There are $6! = 720$ ways to put the beads on the grid ignoring distinguishability. On the other hand, there are $4$ possible transformations of the board using rotations and reflections (including the identity): \begin{tabular}{ccccccc}
 A & B & C & & C & B & A\\ D & E & F & & F & E & D \end{tabular}\begin{tabular}{ccccccc} F & E & D & & D & E & F\\ C & B & A & & A & B & C \end{tabular}None of these transformations besides the identity fixes an arrangement, so each arrangement is equivalent to three others.
 As a result, there are $\tfrac{720}{4} = \boxed{180}$ different arrangements.
 *)

theorem
fixes arrangements :: nat
assumes h0 : "arrangements = card {P :: (nat \<times> nat) \<Rightarrow> nat. bij P \<and> (\<forall>i j. P (i, j) \<noteq> P (j, i)) \<and> (\<forall>i j. P (i, j) \<noteq> P (2 - i, j)) \<and> (\<forall>i j. P (i, j) \<noteq> P (i, 3 - j))}"
shows  "arrangements = 180"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem:
Find the number of arrangements of a function $P: (i, j) ightarrow n$ such that $P$ is bijective, $P(i, j) 
eq P(j, i)$, $P(i, j) 
eq P(2-i, j)$, and $P(i, j) 
eq P(i, 3-j)$. The total number of such arrangements is 180.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes arrange :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "arrange 6 = 6!"
and h1 : "count_rotations_and_reflections = 4"
shows  "distinct_arrangements = arrange 6 div count_rotations_and_reflections"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many ways are there to arrange $6$ beads of distinct colors in a $2 \times 3$ grid if reflections and rotations are considered the same? (In other words, two arrangements are considered the same if I can rotate and/or reflect one arrangement to get the other.) The final Answer is 180
 ### Proof
 There are $6! = 720$ ways to put the beads on the grid ignoring distinguishability. On the other hand, there are $4$ possible transformations of the board using rotations and reflections (including the identity): \begin{tabular}{ccccccc}
 A & B & C & & C & B & A\\ D & E & F & & F & E & D \end{tabular}\begin{tabular}{ccccccc} F & E & D & & D & E & F\\ C & B & A & & A & B & C \end{tabular}None of these transformations besides the identity fixes an arrangement, so each arrangement is equivalent to three others.
 As a result, there are $\tfrac{720}{4} = \boxed{180}$ different arrangements.
 *)

theorem
fixes arrange :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "arrange 6 = 6!"
and h1 : "count_rotations_and_reflections = 4"
shows  "distinct_arrangements = arrange 6 div count_rotations_and_reflections"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Find the number of distinct arrangements of a hexagon, considering rotations and reflections. Given that there are 6! ways to arrange the vertices of a hexagon, and that there are 4 possible rotations and reflections, calculate the number of distinct arrangements.
